00020 namespace RandomLib {
00021   /**
00022    * \brief Sample exactly from a normal distribution.
00023    *
00024    * Sample \e x from exp(-<i>x</i><sup>2</sup>/2) / sqrt(2 pi).  For
00025    * background, see:
00026    * - J. von Neumann, Various Techniques used in Connection with Random
00027    *   Digits, J. Res. Nat. Bur. Stand., Appl. Math. Ser. 12, 36-38 (1951),
00028    *   reprinted in Collected Works, Vol. 5, 768-770 (Pergammon, 1963).
00029    * - D. E. Knuth and A. C. Yao, The Complexity of Nonuniform Random Number
00030    *   Generation, in "Algorithms and Complexity" (Academic Press, 1976),
00031    *   pp. 357-428.
00032    * - P. Flajolet and N. Saheb, The Complexity of Generating an
00033    *   Exponentially Distributed Variate, J. Algorithms 7, 463-488 (1986).
00034    *
00035    * The algorithm is as follows:
00036    * -# Select an integer \e k >= 0 with probability
00037    *    exp(-<i>k</i>/2) (1-exp(-1/2)).
00038    * -# Accept with probability
00039    *    exp(- \e k (\e k - 1) / 2); otherwise, reject and start over at step 1.
00040    * -# Sample a random number \e x uniformly from [0,1).
00041    * -# Accept with probability exp(- \e x (\e x + 2\e k) / 2);
00042    *    otherwise, reject and start over at step 1.
00043    * -# Set \e x = \e k + \e x.
00044    * -# With probability 1/2, negate \e x.
00045    * -# Return \e x.
00046    * .
00047    * It is easy to show that this algorithm returns samples from the normal
00048    * distribution with zero mean and unit variance.  Futhermore, all these
00049    * steps can be carried out exactly as follows:
00050    * - Step 1:
00051    *  - \e k = 0;
00052    *  - while (ExpProb(-1/2)) increment \e k by 1.
00053    * - Step 2:
00054    *  - \e n = \e k (\e k - 1) / 2;
00055    *  - while (\e n > 0)
00056    *    { if (!ExpProb(-1/2)) go to step 1; decrement \e n by 1; }
00057    * - Step 4:
00058    *  - repeat \e k + 1 times:
00059    *    if (!ExpProb(- \e x (\e x + 2\e k) / (2\e k + 2))) go to step 1.
00060    * .
00061    * Here, ExpProb(-\e p) returns true with probability exp(-\e p).  With \e p
00062    * = 1/2 (steps 1 and 2), this is implemented with von Neumann's rejection
00063    * technique:
00064    * - Generate a sequence of random numbers <i>U</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> and
00065    *   find the greatest \e n such that 1/2 > <i>U</i><sub>1</sub> >
00066    *   <i>U</i><sub>2</sub> > . . . > <i>U</i><sub><i>n</i></sub>.  (The
00067    *   resulting value of \e n may be 0.)
00068    * - If \e n is even, accept and return true; otherwise (\e n odd), reject
00069    *   and return false.
00070    * .
00071    * For \e p = \e x (\e x + 2\e k) / (2\e k + 2) (step 4), we generalize von
00072    * Neumann's procedure as follows:
00073    * - Generate two sequences of random numbers <i>U</i><sub><i>i</i></sub>
00074    *   and  <i>V</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> and find the greatest \e n such that
00075    *   both the following conditions hold
00076    *   - \e x > <i>U</i><sub>1</sub> > <i>U</i><sub>2</sub> > . . . >
00077    *      <i>U</i><sub><i>n</i></sub>;
00078    *   - \e x + 2 \e k > (2 \e k + 2) <i>V</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> for all \e i
00079    *     in [1, \e n].
00080    *   .
00081    *   (The resulting value of \e n may be 0.)
00082    * - If \e n is even, accept (return true); otherwise (\e n odd), reject
00083    *   (return false).
00084    * .
00085    * Here, instead of testing \e x + 2 \e k > (2 \e k + 2)
00086    * <i>V</i><sub><i>i</i></sub>, we carry out the following tests:
00087    * - return true, with probability 2 \e k / (2 \e k + 2);
00088    * - return false, with probability 1 / (2 \e k + 2);
00089    * - otherwise (also with probability 1 / (2 \e k + 2)),
00090    *   return \e x > <i>V</i><sub><i>i</i></sub>.
00091    * .
00092    * The resulting method now entails evaluation of simple fractional
00093    * probabilities (e.g., 1 / (2 \e k + 2)), or comparing random numbers (e.g.,
00094    * <i>U</i><sub>1</sub> > <i>U</i><sub>2</sub>).  These may be carried out
00095    * exactly with a finite mean running time.
00096    *
00097    * With \e
00098    * bits = 1, this consumes 30.0 digits on average and the result has 1.56
00099    * digits in the fraction.  It takes about 676 ns to generate a result (1460
00100    * ns, including the time to round it to a double).  With bits = 32, it takes
00101    * 437 ns to generate a result (621 ns, including the time to round it to a
00102    * double).  In contrast, NormalDistribution takes about 44 ns to generate a
00103    * double result.
00104    *
00105    * Another way of assessing the efficiency of the algorithm is thru the mean
00106    * value of the balance = (number of random bits consumed) - (number of bits
00107    * in the result).  If we code the result in Knuth & Yao's unary-binary
00108    * notation, then the mean balance is 26.1.
00109    *
00110    * For example the following samples from a normal exponential distribution
00111    * and prints various representations of the result.
00112    * \code
00113 #include <RandomLib/RandomNumber.hpp>
00114 #include <RandomLib/ExactNormal.hpp>
00115 
00116   RandomLib::Random r;
00117   const int bits = 1;
00118   RandomLib::ExactNormal<bits> ndist;
00119   for (size_t i = 0; i < 10; ++i) {
00120     RandomLib::RandomNumber<bits> x = ndist(r); // Sample
00121     std::pair<double, double> z = x.Range();
00122     std::cout << x << " = "     // Print in binary with ellipsis
00123               << "(" << z.first << "," << z.second << ")"; // Print range
00124     double v = x.Value<double>(r); // Round exactly to nearest double
00125     std::cout << " = " << v << "\n";
00126   }
00127 \endcode
00128    * Here's a possible result:
00129 \verbatim
00130 -1.00... = (-1.25,-1) = -1.02142
00131 -0.... = (-1,0) = -0.319708
00132 0.... = (0,1) = 0.618735
00133 -0.0... = (-0.5,0) = -0.396591
00134 0.0... = (0,0.5) = 0.20362
00135 0.0... = (0,0.5) = 0.375662
00136 -1.111... = (-2,-1.875) = -1.88295
00137 -1.10... = (-1.75,-1.5) = -1.68088
00138 -0.... = (-1,0) = -0.577547
00139 -0.... = (-1,0) = -0.890553
00140 \endverbatim
00141    * First number is in binary with ... indicating an infinite sequence of
00142    * random bits.  Second number gives the corresponding interval.  Third
00143    * number is the result of filling in the missing bits and rounding exactly
00144    * to the nearest representable double.
00145    *
00146    * This class uses some mutable RandomNumber objects.  So a single
00147    * ExactNormal object cannot safely be used by multiple threads.  In a
00148    * multi-processing environment, each thread should use a thread-specific
00149    * ExactNormal object.  In addition, these should be invoked with
00150    * thread-specific random generator objects.
00151    *
00152    * @tparam bits the number of bits in each digit.
00153    **********************************************************************/
00154   template<int bits = 1> class ExactNormal {
00155   public:
00156     /**
00157      * Return a random deviate with a normal distribution of mean 0 and
00158      * variance 1.
00159      *
00160      * @tparam Random the type of the random generator.
00161      * @param[in,out] r a random generator.
00162      * @return the random sample.
00163      **********************************************************************/
00164     template<class Random> RandomNumber<bits> operator()(Random& r) const;
00165   private:
00166 
00167     /**
00168      * Return true with probability exp(-1/2).  For \e bits = 1, this consumes,
00169      * on average, \e t = 2.84525 random digits.  We have \e t = \e a
00170      * (1-exp(-1/2)) + \e b exp(-1/2), where \e a is the mean bit count for
00171      * false result = 5.3441 and \e b is the mean bit count for true result =
00172      * 6.8258.
00173      **********************************************************************/
00174     template<class Random> bool ExpProbH(Random& r) const;
00175 
00176     /**
00177      * Return true with probability exp(-<i>n</i>/2).  For \e bits = 1, this
00178      * consumes, on average, \e t (1-exp(-<i>n</i>/2))/(1-exp(-1/2)) random
00179      * digits.  A true result uses \e n \e b random digits.  A false result
00180      * uses \e a + \e b [exp(-1/2)/(1-exp(-1/2)) -
00181      * <i>n</i> exp(-<i>n</i>/2)/(1-exp(-<i>n</i>/2))] random digits.
00182      **********************************************************************/
00183     template<class Random> bool ExpProb(Random& r, unsigned n) const;
00184 
00185     /**
00186      * Return \e n with probability exp(-<i>n</i>/2) (1-exp(-1/2)).  For \e
00187      * bits = 1, this consumes \e n \e a + \e b random digits if the result is
00188      * \e n.  Averaging over \e n this becomes (\e b - (\e b - \e a)
00189      * exp(-1/2))/(1 - exp(-1/2)) digits.
00190      **********************************************************************/
00191     template<class Random> unsigned ExpProbN(Random& r) const;
00192 
00193     /**
00194      * Return true with probability 1/2.  This is similar to r.Boolean() but
00195      * forces all the random results to come thru RandomNumber::RandomDigit.
00196      **********************************************************************/
00197     template<class Random> static bool Boolean(Random& r) {
00198       // A more general implementation which deals with the case where the base
00199       // might be negative is:
00200       //
00201       //   const unsigned base = 1u << bits;
00202       //   unsigned b;
00203       //   do
00204       //     b = RandomNumber<bits>::RandomDigit(r);
00205       //   while (b == (base / 2) * 2);
00206       //   return b & 1u;
00207       return RandomNumber<bits>::RandomDigit(r) & 1u;
00208     }
00209 
00210     /**
00211      * Implement outcomes for choosing with prob (\e x + 2\e k) / (2\e k + 2);
00212      * return:
00213      * - 1 (succeed unconditionally) with prob (2\e k) / (2\e k + 2),
00214      * - 0 (succeed with probability x) with prob 1 / (2\e k + 2),
00215      * - -1 (fail unconditionally) with prob 1 / (2\e k + 2).
00216      * .
00217      * This simulates \code
00218   double x = r.Fixed();  // Uniform in [0,1)
00219   x *= (2 * k + 2);
00220   return x < 2 * k ? 1 : (x < 2 * k + 1 ? 0 : -1);
00221 \endcode
00222      **********************************************************************/
00223     template<class Random> static int Choose(Random& r, int k) {
00224       // Limit base to 2^15 to avoid integer overflow
00225       const int b = bits > 15 ? 15 : bits;
00226       const unsigned mask = (1u << b) - 1;
00227       const int m = 2 * k + 2;
00228       int n1 = m - 2, n2 = m - 1;
00229       // Evaluate u < n/m where u is a random real number in [0,1).  Write u =
00230       // (d + u') / 2^b where d is a random integer in [0,2^b) and u' is in
00231       // [0,1).  Then u < n/m becomes u' < n'/m where n' = 2^b * n - d * m and
00232       // exit if n' <= 0 (false) or n >= m (true).
00233       while (true) {
00234         int d = (mask & RandomNumber<bits>::RandomDigit(r)) * m;
00235         n1 = std::max((n1 << b) - d, 0);
00236         if (n1 >= m) return 1;
00237         n2 = std::min((n2 << b) - d, m);
00238         if (n2 <= 0) return -1;
00239         if (n1 == 0 && n2 == m) return 0;
00240       }
00241     }
00242 
00243     mutable RandomNumber<bits> _x;
00244     mutable RandomNumber<bits> _p;
00245     mutable RandomNumber<bits> _q;
00246   };
00247 
00248   template<int bits> template<class Random>
00249   bool ExactNormal<bits>::ExpProbH(Random& r) const {
00250     // Bit counts
00251     // ExpProbH: 2.8457 = 3.7855 * (1-exp(-1/2)) + 2.2361 * exp(-1/2)
00252     //             t    =   a    * (1-exp(-1/2)) +   b    * exp(-1/2)
00253     // t = mean bit count for       result = 2.8457
00254     // a = mean bit count for false result = 3.7855
00255     // b = mean bit count for true  result = 2.2361
00256     _p.Init();
00257     if (_p.Digit(r, 0) >> (bits - 1))
00258       return true;
00259     while (true) {
00260       _q.Init(); if (!_q.LessThan(r, _p)) return false;
00261       _p.Init(); if (!_p.LessThan(r, _q)) return true;
00262     }
00263   }
00264 
00265   template<int bits> template<class Random>
00266   bool ExactNormal<bits>::ExpProb(Random& r, unsigned n) const {
00267     // Bit counts
00268     // ExpProb(n): t * (1-exp(-n/2))/(1-exp(-1/2))
00269     // ExpProb(n) = true: n * b
00270     // ExpProb(n) = false: a +
00271     //    b * (exp(-1/2)/(1-exp(-1/2)) - n*exp(-n/2)/(1-exp(-n/2)))
00272     while (n--) {
00273       if (!ExpProbH(r))
00274         return false;
00275     }
00276     return true;
00277   }
00278 
00279   template<int bits> template<class Random>
00280   unsigned ExactNormal<bits>::ExpProbN(Random& r) const {
00281     // Bit counts
00282     // ExpProbN() = n: n * a + b
00283     unsigned n = 0;
00284     while (ExpProbH(r)) ++n;
00285     return n;
00286   }
00287 
00288   template<int bits> template<class Random> RandomNumber<bits>
00289   ExactNormal<bits>::operator()(Random& r) const {
00290     // With bits = 1,
00291     // - mean number of bits used = 29.99968
00292     // - mean number of bits in fraction = 1.55580
00293     // - mean number of bits in result = 3.92137 (unary-binary)
00294     // - mean balance = 31.18542 - 3.90762 = 26.07831
00295     // - mean number of bits to generate a double = 82.86049
00296     // .
00297     // Note
00298     // - unary-binary notation (Knuth + Yao, 1976): write x = n + y, with n =
00299     //   integer and y in [0,1).  If n >=0, then write (n+1) 1's followed by a
00300     //   0; otherwise (n < 0), write (-n) 0's followed by a 1.  Write y as a
00301     //   binary fraction.
00302     // - (bits in result) - (bits in fraction) = 2 (for encoding overhead for
00303     //   the integer part) + 0.36557, where 0.36557 = (bits used for integer
00304     //   part) = sum(k*int(sqrt(2/pi)*exp(-x^2/2), x=k..k+1), k=0..inf)
00305     // - (bits for double) approx (bits used) - (bits in fraction) + 1 (for
00306     //   guard bit) + 53.41664 where 53.41664 = (bits in fraction of double) =
00307     //   sum((52-l)*int(sqrt(2/pi)*exp(-x^2/2), x=2^l,2^(l+1)), l=-inf..inf)
00308     //   This is approximate because it doesn't account for the minimum
00309     //   exponent, denormalized numbers, and rounding changing the exponent.
00310     //
00311     while (true) {
00312       // Executed sqrt(2/pi)/(1-exp(-1/2)) = 2.027818889827955 times on
00313       // average.
00314       unsigned k = ExpProbN(r); // the integer part of the result.
00315       if (ExpProb(r, (k - 1) * k)) {
00316         // Probability that this test succeeds is
00317         // (1 - exp(-1/2)) * sum(exp(-k/2) * exp(-(k-1)*k/2), k=0..inf))
00318         //  = (1 - exp(-1/2)) * G = 0.7391491050895928
00319         // where G = sum(exp(-k^2/2, k=0..inf) = 1.753314144021453
00320         // For k == 0, sample from exp(-x^2/2) for x in [0,1].  This succeeds
00321         // with probability int(exp(-x^2/2),x=0..1).
00322         //
00323         // For general k, substitute x' = x + k in exp(-x'^2/2), and obtain
00324         // exp(-k^2/2) * exp(-x*(x+2*k)/2).  So sample from exp(-x*(x+2*k)/2).
00325         // This succeeds with probability int(exp(-x*(x+2*k)/2),x=0..1) =
00326         // int(exp(-x^2/2),x=k..k+1)*exp(k^2/2) =
00327         //
00328         //    0.8556243918921 for k = 0
00329         //    0.5616593588061 for k = 1
00330         //    0.3963669350376 for k = 2
00331         //    0.2974440159655 for k = 3
00332         //    0.2345104783458 for k = 4
00333         //    0.1921445042826 for k = 5
00334         //
00335         // Returns a result with prob sqrt(pi/2) / G = 0.714825772431666;
00336         // otherwise another trip through the outer loop is taken.
00337         _x.Init();
00338         unsigned s = 1;
00339         for (unsigned j = 0; j <= k; ++j) { // execute k + 1 times
00340           bool first;
00341           for (s = 1, first = true; ; s ^= 1, first = false) {
00342             // Split off the failure test for k == 0, i.e., factor the prob x/2
00343             // test into the product: 1/2 (here) times x (in assignment of y).
00344             if (k == 0 && Boolean(r)) break;
00345             // A variation which reduces the number of bits in the fraction to
00346             // 1.18699 (from 1.55580), at the expense of increasing the number
00347             // of bits required to 31.15505 (from 29.99968) and the balance to
00348             // 27.60249 (from 26.07831) is to change the test on the first
00349             // iteration through this loop to max(q, p) < x.
00350             _q.Init(); if (!_q.LessThan(r, first ? _x : _p)) break;
00351             // succeed with prob k == 0 ? x : (x + 2*k) / (2*k + 2)
00352             int y = k == 0 ? 0 : Choose(r, k);
00353             if (y < 0)
00354               break;
00355             else if (y == 0) {
00356               _p.Init(); if (!_p.LessThan(r, _x)) break;
00357             }
00358             _p.swap(_q);        // a fast way of doing p = q
00359           }
00360           if (s == 0) break;
00361         }
00362         if (s != 0) {
00363           _x.AddInteger(k);
00364           if (Boolean(r)) _x.Negate(); // half of the numbers are negative
00365           return _x;
00366         }
00367       }
00368     }
00369   }
